newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgium's Generale Bank buys Harbour Capital. [CORRECTED 19:30 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Belgium's Generale Bank buys Harbour Capital. [CORRECTED 19:30 GMT]

text.p: (Corrects spelling of company being acquired from Harbor Capital to Harbour Capital.)
Belgium's biggest bank, Generale Bank, along with its French unit Fimagest, said Wednesday it will buy a controlling stake in Boston-based fund manager Harbour Capital Management Company Inc.

Generale Bank Managing Director Andre Bergen told a news conference the two would buy at least a 51 percent stake in HCM with a seven-year option to raise its share to 75 percent. The deal is subject to regulatory and minority shareholder approval.

The price paid for the stake in Harbour Capital Management, or HCM, would be based on the company's estimated value of $50 million, with the cost split 66 percent to 33 percent between Generale and Fimagest.
"This is below the average market price, but ... HCM personnel will remain shareholders and will be closely interested in the evolution of the company," Bergen said.
HCM manages $5 billion in assets for 200 clients, including pension funds and individuals.
HCM is 85 percent owned by company employees. The rest is held by Switzerland's Julius Baer Holding.
Bergen said Generale would, as part of the deal, acquire about two-thirds of the Swiss holding's stake.
"The partnership (with HCM) basically completes the international presence we wanted to have in fund management, based on a strategic decision taken in 1994," Bergen said.
He said the deal would lift Generale Bank's total funds under management to $57 billion, of which 60 percent is in mutual funds and the remainder in private asset management.
"With this acquisition we are the first Belgian bank to put its asset management on a global basis," Bergen said.
Generale Bank now has operations in Europe, Asia and the United States.
